elements.text: Two questions: 1) Does a generic struct increase performance? If I have something like this, is this perfectly acceptable?
and if I know the sizes of
is there a way I can preallocate? Maybe

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

increase performance compare to what? I think the answer is no.

Allocation happens when you make a instance, you can make a constructor that pre-allocate

elements.text:
increase performance compare to what? I think the answer is no.

Allocation happens when you make a instance, you can make a constructor that pre-allocate

text:
No. But using a generic type might be a bit cleaner since you're letting the compiler auto-infer the array type rather than typing it out yourself. It's also better for extensibility since alternative array types can be used.

The only thing that would theoretically increase performance here is using `SArray` or `Tuple` s or something where the length is statically known.

elements.text:
No. But using a generic type might be a bit cleaner since you're letting the compiler auto-infer the array type rather than typing it out yourself. It's also better for extensibility since alternative array types can be used.

The only thing that would theoretically increase performance here is using
s or something where the length is statically known.

text: Also, `SVector` will only be better up until a certain point. Once the array gets big enough, a heap allocated array will be faster.

elements.text: will only be better up until a certain point. Once the array gets big enough, a heap allocated array will be faster.
